story.text: (Updates figures, adds comment)TORONTO Jan 2 (Reuters) - The Toronto Stock Exchange's main index kicked off the first trading session of 2007 with a broad rally on Tuesday, as resource, financial and energy shares helped drive morning gains. The S&P/TSX composite .GSPTSE rose 76.84 points, or 0.6 percent, to 12,985.23 shortly after the opening bell. All but one of the composite's 10 key groups advanced, with the resource-laden materials group rising 1.2 percent and energy moving forward 0.65 percent. Financials rose 0.25 percent. Utilities and information technology declined. Given the breadth of the rally, early 2007 could see an extension of the strength shown by the composite in the fourth quarter of last year, said Ian Nakamoto, director of research at MacDougall, MacDougall & MacTier. "I think...2007 is going to be another good year, but I think a lot of it could be sort of front-end loaded in the first few months," he said. He added that while investors realize the index returned 14.5 percent in 2006, their enthusiasm is measured. "People notice, obviously, that the market has done well, but I don't get the general sense people are throwing caution to the wind at all," he said, pointing to price-to-earnings ratios which he described as relatively low. Harris Steel Group Inc. HSG.TO was among Tuesday's top gainers after it announced a takeover offer from U.S.-based Nucor Corp. (NUE.N) before markets opened. The all-cash offer values Harris at C$1.25 billion ($1.08 billion). The steelmaker's shares rose C$2.76, or 6.4 percent, to C$46.25, matching the per-share bid price. Among energy names, Suncor Energy Inc. (SU.TO) rose 99 Canadian cents to C$92.78 and Husky Energy (HSE.TO) gained 38 Canadian cents to C$78.42. Gold issues on the rise included Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd.(AEM.TO), which picked up 76 Canadian cents to C$48.85, and Barrick Gold Corp. which rose 55 Canadian cents to C$36.40. The price of gold also rose on Tuesday, as the euro gained against the U.S. dollar. The greenback's declines can spur demand for bullion and for the shares of companies that mine it. New year's trades were put off one more day in the United States, as exchanges stayed shut to observe a day of mourning for the death of former U.S. President Gerald Ford. "The fact that the U.S. is closed means that there'll be a cautious tone, no matter what, because we won't have that input," said Paul Taylor, chief investment officer at BMO Harris Private Banking. ($1=$1.16 Canadian)
story.title: toronto stocks kick off 2007 with broadbased rally
